THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				I. Jenkins Mikell, Jr. and Pinkney V. Mikell, Petitioners,
				v.
				County of
      Charleston and Timothy E. Scott, A.D. Jordan, Curtis E. Bostic, Carolyn
      Condon, Ed Fava, Barrett Lawrimore, Francis J. Roberts, Leon E. Stavrinakis,
      and Charles T. Wallace in their capacity as Members of Charleston County
      Council, George Lee Mikell, Julia Mikell Flowers, Daisy Mikell Pedrick, Mary
      Mikell, John Mikell, and Peters Point Associates, LP, Defendants,
				of whom George
      Lee Mikell, Julia Mikell Flowers, Daisy Mikell Pedrick, Mary Mikell, John
      Mikell, and Peters Point Associates, LP are the Respondents.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal From Charleston County
Â Mikell R. Scarborough, Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No.Â Â  26749
Heard May 12, 2009 - Filed December 21,
  2009
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Capers
  G. Barr, III, of Barr, Unger & McIntosh, of Charleston, Frances I.
  Cantwell, and William B. Regan, both of Regan & Cantwell, of Charleston,
  for Petitioners.
				Carolyn
  H. Blue, of Tecklenburg Law Firm, of Charleston, Morris A. Ellison, of Buist,
  Moore, Smythe & McGee, of Charleston, Perrin O. Dargan, III, of Hagood
  & Kerr, of Mount Pleasant, for Respondents.
				James
  M Brailsford, III, of Edisto Island, for Amicus Curiae SC Coastal Conservation League. 
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  WALLER: We granted a writ of
  certiorari to review Mikell v. County of Charleston, 375 S.C. 552, 654
  S.E.2d 92 (Ct. App. 2007), in which the Court of Appeals held Charleston County
  Council (County) properly enacted a zoning ordinance for a Planned Development
  (PD) on Edisto Island.Â  We reverse.Â  
FACTS
The property in question is a 160 acre tract of land
  on Edisto Island which is known as Peters Point Plantation, a former cotton
  plantation owned by the Mikell family since 1715.Â  Â Peters Point forms a point, or peninsula, at the intersection of two tidal creeks: St. Pierreâ€™s Creek
  on the north, and Fishing Creek on the south.Â  
Peters Point is intersected in the middle by Peters Point Road.Â  Petitioners are I. Jenkins Mikell, Jr. and Pinkney V. Mikell, who own land on the north side of Peters Point Road; Respondents, distant family members of Petitioners, own six tracts of
  land, a total of 161 acres, on the north and south of Peters Point Road.Â  The
  furthermost tract borders Fishing Creek.Â Â  
In 1999, Charleston County enacted a Comprehensive Land Use Plan (Plan).Â  The Plan describes that
  the â€œAgricultural Area is the outmost portion of the Rural Landscape in Charleston County.Â  Included within it are Wadmalaw Island, Edisto Island [and others].â€Â 
  The Plan calls for preservation of the rural community character.Â  The
  preferred uses of agricultural areas include â€œfarming and resource management,
  along with preservation of existing rural settlements, compatible low-density
  residential development, and small-scale neighborhood commercial development.â€Â  Id.Â Â  The recommended development densities within such Agricultural
  Areas of Charleston County are as follows:

	-Agricultural
  Residential (AGR) - 1 dwelling per acre to 1 dwelling per 5 acres.
	-Agricultural
  Preservation (AG-10) - 1 dwelling per 5 acres to 1 dwelling per 10 acres. 

The Plan states â€œthe
  designation of Agricultural Areas is also intended to direct residential
  development to existing settlement areas and to avoid the scattering of
  development into . . . Agricultural Preservation Areas.â€Â  
In 2001, County
  enacted Zoning and Land Development Regulations (ZLDR) in order to implement
  the Plan.Â  The ZLDR incorporate the Agricultural Areas of the Plan, and reiterate
  that an AG-10 Agricultural Preservation District is subject to a maximum
  density of 1 dwelling per 10 acres.Â  ZLDR Â§ 4.5.Â  However, an AG-10
  district may be increased to a â€œhighest allowed densityâ€ of 1 dwelling unit per
  5 acres, if a request is processed through the Planned Development process of Â§
  3.5 of the ZLDR.Â  The ZLDR sets the maximum density for AGR districts at 1
  dwelling per acre, in accordance with the Plan.Â  
Under the Plan and
  the ZLDR, of the six tracts of land owned by Respondents, four of the tracts
  were zoned AGR, and the remaining two tracts were zoned AG-10, such that the
  total parcel of 161 acres was subject to maximum densities as follows:

	-106.64
  Acres (2 tracts)- Zoned AG-10-Â Â  1 unit per 10 acres = total 10 units[1] 
	-55
  Acres (4 tracts)- Zoned AGR-Â Â  1 unit per acre = 54 total units.

Accordingly, as initially
  zoned, the tracts were subject to a total maximum of 64 units.
In 2003,
  Respondents filed an application with County to rezone their Peters Point property to a Planned Development (PD) District.Â  The stated purpose of the
  application was to allow family members to construct homes for themselves and
  their children at Peterâ€™s Point Plantation; they do not intend to permit
  commercial or multi-family development.Â  On May 4, 2004, County Council enacted
  Ordinance # 1300 rezoning the parcels from AGR and AG-10 to a PD-103 District.Â 
  The Planned Development submitted by Respondents (and approved by Ordinance #
  1300) had the effect of reducing the total number of units on the entire tract
  from a maximum of 64, to a total maximum of 55 units.Â  However, the Ordinance
  also had the effect of increasing the overall density to 1 dwelling unit per
  3.8 acres.Â  As to the 106 acre tract of land which was zoned AG-10, the PD had
  the effect of increasing to a maximum density of 1 unit per 2.4 acres.
Petitioners
  instituted this declaratory judgment action, contending the ordinance
  conflicted with Countyâ€™s Comprehensive Plan and the ZLDR.Â  Petitionersâ€™ motion
  for summary judgment was granted by the Master.Â  The Master held Ordinance #
  1300 conflicted with the clear, unambiguous requirements of Â§ 4.5.3(B) of the
  ZLDR limiting the density in an AG-10 district to a maximum of one dwelling per
  five acres.Â  The Master found Â§ 4.5.3 was, at best, inconsistent with Â§ 3.5.7
  of the ZLDR, such that the more specific regulation, Â§ 4.5.3, controlled.Â  
The Court of
  Appeals reversed.Â  Mikell v. County of Charleston, 375 S.C. 552, 654
  S.E.2d 92 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  It held County Councilâ€™s decision to allow the PD
  was at least fairly debatable, and was neither arbitrary nor unreasonable.Â Â  It
  found Â§ 3.5.2 and Â§ 3.5.7 of the ZLDR authorized Countyâ€™s exercise of
  discretion in approving a PD with a higher density than base zoning districts
  would have allowed.Â  The Court of Appeals found no conflict existed between Â§Â§
  3.5.2, 3.5.7 and Â§ 4.5.3(B).Â  We reverse.Â  
ISSUE
Did the Court of
  Appeals err in reversing the Masterâ€™s grant of summary judgment to Petitioners
  and reinstating Ordinance # 1300?
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Although summary judgment issues are generally
  reviewed under a fact-based inquiry, issues involving the construction of an
  ordinance are reviewed as a matter of law under a broader standard of review
  than is applied in reviewing issues of fact.Â  Eagle Container LLC v. County of Newberry, 379 S.C. 564, 666 S.E.2d 892 (2008).Â  Although great deference is
  accorded the decisions of those charged with interpreting and applying local
  zoning ordinances, â€œa broader and more independent review is permitted when the
  issue concerns the construction of an ordinance.â€Â  Id. at 568, 666
  S.E.2d at 894 citing Charleston County Parks & Recreation Commâ€™n
    v. Somers, 319 S.C. 65, 67, 459 S.E.2d 841, 843 (1995).Â  The determination
  of legislative intent is a matter of law.Â  Id.[2]Â  
DISCUSSION
Countyâ€™s
  Comprehensive Land Use Plan establishes four distinct areas within County, and sets
  forth the general types and intensities of development which should occur in
  each.Â  The only areas pertinent to this case are those designated as
  Agricultural, for which there are two categories:

	Â -
  Agricultural Residential (AGR) - 1 dwelling per acre to 1 dwelling per 5 acres.
	- Agricultural
  Preservation (AG-10) - 1 dwelling per 5 acres to 1 dwelling per 10 acres. 

The ZLDR passed by
  County to implement the Plan requires an AG-10 District to have a maximum
  density of 1 dwelling per 10 acres.Â  ZLDR Â§ 4.5.2.Â Â  However, this
  density may be increased to a â€œhighest allowed densityâ€ of 1 dwelling
    unit per 5 acres, if a request is processed through the Planned
      Development process of Â§ 3.5 of the ZLDR.Â  ZLDR Â§ 4.5.3.B.Â  Â Â 

	Section 3.5.7 of
  the ZLDR states:
	Unless
  expressly stated in this section or approved at the time of a Planned
  Development approval, all applicable standards of this Ordinance shall apply .
  . . . Planned Developments may provided for variations from other ordinances
    and the regulations of the other established zoning districts concerning use,
    setbacks, lot area, density, bulk and other requirements to accommodate
  flexibility in the arrangement of uses for the general purpose of promoting and
  protecting the public health, safety, and general welfare.Â  

(Emphasis supplied).[3]Â  
The Court of
  Appeals held that inasmuch as Â§ 3.5.7 permits the Commission to approve a PD
  with a higher density than other established zoning districts, the action of
  the Commission in approving respondentsâ€™ application was at least â€œfairly
  debatable.â€Â  The Court of Appeals also held that, because County has the
  legislative power to amend its general zoning ordinance and rezone small areas,
  it acted within its authority.Â  This was error.Â  
The primary rule of
  statutory construction is to ascertain and give effect to the intent of the
  legislature.Â  Mid-State Auto Auction of Lexington, Inc. v. Altman, 324
  S.C. 65, 69, 476 S.E.2d 690, 692 (1996).Â  When interpreting an ordinance, the legislative
  intent must prevail if it can be reasonably discovered in the language used.Â  Charleston County Parks & Recreation Commâ€™n v. Somers, 319 S.C.
  65, 67, 459 S.E.2d 841, 843 (1995). Â Further, where two provisions deal with
  the same issue, one in a general and the other in a more specific and definite
  manner, the more specific prevails.Â  Capco of Summerville v. J.H. Gayle
    Constr. Co., Inc., 368 S.C. 137, 628 S.E.2d 38 (2006).Â  See also Wooten
      ex rel. Wooten v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 333 S.C. 464, 468, 511 S.E.2d 355,
  357 (1999) (specific statutory provision prevails over a more general one); Atlas
    Food Sys. & Servs., Inc. v. Crane Natâ€™l Vendors Div. of Unidynamics Corp.,
  319 S.C. 556, 558, 462 S.E.2d 858, 859 (1995) (general rule of statutory
  construction is that a specific statute prevails over a more general one).Â 
  When reviewing issues involving the construction of an ordinance, the determination
  of legislative intent is a matter of law.Â  Eagle Container, supra.Â Â Â Â  
We find the
  legislative intent, as it relates to AG-10 districts, was to ensure a maximum density of 1 dwelling unit per 5 acres on AG-10 districts.Â  This intent is
  clearly reflected in the Comprehensive Land Use Plan and the ZLDR. Â Â Â Â 
We find it highly
  implausible that, in setting forth a maximum density of 1 unit per 10 acres for
  AG-10 Districts, and then allowing for an increase of up to 1 unit per 5
  acres for a Planned Development, the County intended to authorize the approval
  of a Planned Development which would completely vitiate the maximum density
  requirements set forth in Â§ 4.5.3B.Â Â  Had County intended such a result, Â§
  4.5.3B would have permitted a higher density to be approved if processed
  as a Planned Development, without restricting it to a â€œhighest allowed
    density of 1 unit per 5 acres.â€Â  We find County clearly intended to limit
  those tracts zoned AG-10 to a maximum density of one dwelling per 5 acres, and
  intended to preserve â€œexisting rural settlementsâ€ and â€œcompatible low-density
  residential development.â€Â  It was, therefore, error to authorize maximum
  densities in excess of those specifically outlined by the ZLDR.Â  The Court of
  Appealsâ€™ opinion is reversed, and the order of the Master is reinstated.Â  
REVERSED.Â  
TOAL, C.J.,
  PLEICONES, J., and Acting Justice James E. Moore, concur. Acting Justice G.
  Thomas Cooper dissenting in a separate opinion.

Acting Justice G.
  Thomas Cooper, Â (dissenting): This Court would reverse not only the Court of
  Appeals, but also the Charleston County Planning and Zoning Commission and the
  Charleston County Council for enactment of Ordinance #1300, the Peters Point
  Planned Development.Â  Ordinance #1300 created a Planned Development, an entity
  described and authorized in Section 6-29-740 of the South Carolina Code as an
  independent, distinct zoning district.Â  In doing so, the majority finds:

	â€¦ it
  highly implausible that, in setting forth a maximum density of 1 unit per 10
  acres for AG-10 Districts, and then allowing for an increase of up to 1 unit
  per 5 acres for a Planned Development, the County intended to authorize the
  approval of a Planned Development which would completely vitiate the maximum
  density requirements set forth in Section 4.5.3B.

However, that is exactly what the Act and the
  Charleston County Zoning and Land Development Regulations (ZLDR) allows the
  Charleston County Council to do.Â  Its decision is supported by the State
  statute and the Charleston County Comprehensive Plan and the Charleston County
  ZLDR.Â  To reverse the action of County Council flies in the face of this
  Court's frequent pronouncement that it will acknowledge and respect the actions
  of the pertinent legislative body if its actions are â€œfairly debatable.â€Â  Bear
    Enterprises v. County of Greenville, 319 S.C. 137, 459 S.E.2d 883 (S.C. Ct.
  App. 1995); Rush v. City of Greenville, 246 S.C. 268, 143 S.E.2d 527
  (1965).

	Courts have no prerogative to pass upon the
  wisdom of the municipality's decision unless such decision is â€œso unreasonable
  as to impair or destroy citizen's constitutional rightsâ€; and the decision
  should not be overturned by a court so long as the decision is â€œfairly
  debatable.â€Â  This policy of judicial restraint has been echoed in a recent decision.
	We have long recognized the principal that
  the power to zone is exclusively for the legislature and that zoning decisions
  will not be interfered with when made in the exercise of the governing bodyâ€™s
  police power to accomplish the desired end unless there is a plain violation of
  the citizensâ€ constitutional rights.Â  

Knowles v. City of Aiken, 305 S.C. 219, 224, 407 S.E.2d 639, 642 (1991)
  (internal citations omitted).Â  Modern legal treatises frequently define a
  â€œPlanned Districtâ€ as a â€œPlanned Unit Development.â€

	â€œPlanned unit developmentâ€ means an area of
  land, controlled by a landowner, to be developed as a single entity for a
  number of dwelling units, and commercial and industrial uses, if any, the plan
  for which does not correspond in lot size, bulk, or type of dwelling or
  commercial or industrial use, density, lot coverage and required open space to
  the regulations established in any one or more districts created, from time to
  time, under the provisions of a municipal zoning ordinance enacted pursuant to
  the conventional zoning enabling act of the state.

Julian Conrad
  Juergensmeyer & Thomas E. Roberts, Land Use Planning and
Development Regulation
  Law 283 (2007).Â  This definition is
  not dissimilar to South Carolina Code Section 6-29-740.
The essential question
  is, therefore, does the Charleston County Ordinance #1300 conflict with the
  Charleston County Comprehensive Plan or with the ZLDR?Â  And, if so, can the
  County Council enact an Ordinance which overrides the perceived conflict?

	Because
  of its flexibility as a land use approval mechanism, the PUD may create a
  conflict with the formal land use and intensity designations of a comprehensive
  land use plan.Â  The extent to which such a conflict is fatal depends on whether
  the comprehensive plan in the particular jurisdiction is considered advisory
  only, or whether state legislation mandates that local zoning regulations be
  consistent with the comprehensive plan.Â  In those states in which the
  comprehensive plan is advisory only, the courts have rejected arguments that
  approval of a PUD was invalid because it was inconsistent with the
  comprehensive plan or amounted to spot zoning.Â  

Brian W. Blaesser, Discretionary
  Land Use Controls: Avoiding Invitations to Abuse of Discretion 288-289
  (2009 Ed.).
Code Section
  6-29-720 (B) requires that in adopting a zoning ordinance, the regulations must
  be made in accordance with the comprehensive plan for the jurisdiction.Â  The
  comprehensive plan for Charleston County clearly states that the land use plan
  area designations and residential density guidelines are recommendations to the County Council (see County of Charleston Comprehensive Plan Section
  3-2-5b and Section 3-2-8(4)).Â  Similarly, in Evans v. Teton County, 73
  P.2d 84 (Idaho 2003), a neighbor challenged approval of a planned unit
  development and subdivision on the basis of nonconformity with the local plan.
  The Supreme Court of Idaho discussed the relationship as follows:

	A
  comprehensive plan is not a legally controlling zoning law, it serves as a
  guide to local government agencies charged with making zoning decisions â€¦. The
  "in accordance with" language of [the zoning enabling legislation]
  does not require zoning decisions to strictly conform to the land use
  designations of the comprehensive plan â€¦. However, a board of county
  commissioners cannot ignore their comprehensive plan when adopting or amending
  zoning ordinances â€¦. Whether approval of a zone change is "in accordance
  with" the comprehensive plan is a question of fact, which can only be overturned
  when the factual findings supporting the zone change are clearly erroneous.

Julian Conrad
  Juergensmeyer & Thomas E. Roberts, Land Use Planning and
Development Regulation Law 283 (2007).
The court
  conducted its review on the basis of a strong presumption of validity and
  proceeded on the basis that it must affirm the Board of Commissioners unless it
  violated constitutional or statutory standards, exceeded its statutory
  authority, followed unlawful procedures, was not supported by substantial evidence,
  or was arbitrary and capricious.Â  In other words the courts used the â€œfairly
  debatableâ€ standard accorded to legislative decisions.
I disagree with
  the majorityâ€™s holding that the Charleston County Council cannot modify or
  supersede its own zoning ordinance, if done within the confines of South
  Carolina Code Section 6-29-740.Â  The statute plainly states:

	Planned
  development districts may provide for variations from other ordinances and the
  regulations of other established zoning districts concerning use, setbacks, lot
  size, density, bulk, and other requirements to accommodate flexibility in the
  arrangement of uses for the general purpose of promoting and protecting the
  public health, safety, and general welfare.

And,
  when adopted, the planned development district becomes a new and distinct
  zoning district.
Ordinance
  #1300 found â€œâ€¦after thorough consideration, the County Planning Commission
  recommended in favor of the proposed rezoning;â€¦the rezoning complies in all
  respects with Article 3.4 of the Charleston County Zoning and Land Development
  Regulations;â€¦the development plan meets the objectives of Article 3.5 the
  Charleston County Zoning and Land Development Regulations;â€¦and the development
  plan conforms to and implements the Charleston County Comprehensive Plan.â€
In
  my opinion, the Court of Appeals correctly ruled that the County Councilâ€™s
  actions were authorized and not arbitrary, unreasonable, or in devious abuse of
  its discretion if the action of the Council in adopting the ordinance was
  fairly debatable. 


[1]Â  This number could be increased to a maximum of 1
  unit per 5 acres if done through Planned Development process, allowing a total
  maximum of 20 units.Â Â  
[2]Â  As to fact based issues, an appellate court
  applies the same standard as the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Englert,
    Inc. v. LeafGuard USA, Inc., 377 S.C. 129, 659 S.E.2d 496 (2008).Â  
[3] Â County also relies upon S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  6-29-740, which mimics the language of Â§ 3.5.7, relating to planned
  developments and allows variations from other ordinances and regulations
  concerning use, setbacks, lot size, and density.Â  For the reasons set forth

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				 
				v.
				H. Dewain
      Herring, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
Â G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No.Â  26750
Heard June 23, 2009 - Filed December 21,
  2009Â  
AFFIRMED

	
		
			
				Graham
  L. Newman and Richard A. Harpootlian, both of Columbia, and Katherine Carruth
  Goode, of Winnsboro, for Appellant.
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General S.
  Creighton Waters, and Solicitor Warren Blair Giese, all of Columbia, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  WALLER:Â  Appellant, H. Dewain Herring, was convicted of murder and pointing
  and presenting a firearm.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  

FACTS
Herring
  was charged with the January 29, 2006 shooting of an employee of Chastityâ€™s
  Gold Nightclub (Chastityâ€™s), a strip club in Columbia.Â  The facts giving rise
  to the shooting are as follows.
After
  golfing in Aiken with friends on the day of January 28, 2006, at which he had
  consumed numerous beers, Herring stopped by a bar for a few drinks on the way
  home, and then returned home around 7:30 p.m.Â  Herring had a couple more drinks
  at his home with a golfing buddy before the friend left.Â  Herring laid down
  intending to go to sleep, but got up and decided to go a Forest Acres
  restaurant.Â  When the restaurant was closed, Herring changed his mind and went
  to Platinum Plus, a Columbia strip club. Â He had a drink and paid a dancer for
  a lap dance and left Platinum Plus.Â  On his way home, he decided to stop by Chastityâ€™s
  on River Drive; he arrived shortly after 11:00 p.m.Â  According to Herring, he ordered
  a drink at the bar, but he has very little recall of any events for several
  hours thereafter. 
According
  to witnesses and employees of Chastityâ€™s, Herring purchased a drink and paid
  for a $30.00, three minute lap dance from a dancer named Mia.Â  After the lap
  dance, Herring paid Mia for a $300 dance in what was known as the Champagne room.Â Â Â Â  
Mia
  took Herring to the Champagne room and told him to wait while she went to
  freshen up.Â  A bouncer, Carl Weeks, went to check on Herring a few minutes
  later and found him naked and masturbating on the sofa.Â Â  The bouncer told
  Herring he could not do that and told him he would have to leave.Â Â  When
  Herring did not move, the bouncer got the manager, John Johnson (John John).Â 
  When they returned, Herring was dressed.Â  Weeks told Herring he would either
  have to leave, or they would call police and have him arrested for solicitation
  of prostitution.Â  According to Weeks, Herring responded, â€œNo.Â  I will fucking
  shoot you.â€Â Â Â  John John and a bouncer named Donnie Hawkins escorted Herring to
  the front door at 11:57 p.m.Â  John John walked outside with Herring and used a
  two-way radio to call Herringâ€™s license plate number out to Weeks, who was
  standing in the doorway, as Herring drove away.Â  Weeks and Hawkins watched as
  Herring backed up his black SUV, and fumbled with his glove compartment with
  his right hand.Â  Herring slowly pulled away, putting down the passenger side
  windows as he went.Â  Hawkins, Weeks and John John had just gone inside when
  they saw Herringâ€™s vehicle coming back down River Drive toward Chastityâ€™s. Â According
  to Hawkins, John John was right inside the door.Â  Hawkins saw a flash of light
  come from the side of the vehicle, and heard John John say, â€œOh shit!â€Â Â  John
  John fell to the floor, having been hit in the left ear by a bullet which came
  through the front door.Â  He died a short while later at the hospital.
Upon
  arriving at the scene of Chastityâ€™s, police were given Herringâ€™s license tag
  number, which was registered to his office address in Columbia.Â  Police
  patrolled the office parking lot, but did not find the vehicle.Â  They then
  determined Herringâ€™s home address and went there at 2:10 a.m. on January 29,
  2006.Â  A police officer, seeing a light on in the garage, peeked in the garage
  window to see if the suspect was there.Â  Although the suspect was not there,
  the officer did see the vehicle, which they realized was Herringâ€™s.Â  They
  knocked on the door and rang the doorbell several times and, receiving no
  answer, they returned to the police station and obtained a search warrant for
  the home.[2] Â Â Â 
Police
  went back to Herringâ€™s residence at approximately 4:00 a.m. to execute the
  search warrant.Â  They rang the doorbell several times but received no answer.Â 
  They entered forcibly, announcing they were police with a search warrant.Â 
  Officer Linfert testified that he saw Herring in the hallway and recognized him
  from the photo on his driverâ€™s license.Â  Linfert told Herring to get down on
  the ground, but Herring ran back down the hall toward a bedroom.Â  He followed
  Herring to the bedroom, and saw Herring pull a gun from a nightstand and point
  it in his direction.Â  Officer Linfert yelled at him to drop the gun and then
  fired one shot at him.Â  Other officers also opened fire, and Herring was hit in
  the arm.Â  Herring called 9-1-1 and told them he believed there were intruders
  in his home.Â  After talking with the 9-1-1 operator, Herring surrendered upon
  realizing the â€œintrudersâ€ were indeed police officers.Â  
Herring
  initially told police he had not left the house after returning home from Aiken;
  he did not recall going to Chastityâ€™s.Â  When police told him of the video tape which
  showed him entering and leaving Chastityâ€™s, he remembered only being at the
  bar, having a drink, and a gunshot firing; the next memory he had was of police
  bursting into his home.Â  He subsequently began remembering more details, such
  as paying for a lap dance from a light skinned black woman.Â  
Bullet
  fragments removed from John Johnâ€™s head conclusively matched a .357 Magnum Ruger owned by Herring; the Ruger was found under some clothing in his bedroom
  closet during a SLED search of the home.[3]Â 
  Gunshot residue was found on the passenger side of Herringâ€™s vehicle.Â  A jury
  convicted Herring of murder and pointing and presenting a firearm.
ISSUES

	1.Â  Did the trial court err in denying Herringâ€™s motions
  to suppress evidence found during the search of his residence?
	2.Â  Did the trial court err in allowing lay witnesses to
  testify as to their opinion of what could be seen on a videotape which recorded
  Herring as he exited Chastityâ€™s? 

1.Â  SEARCH WARRANTS/SUPPRESSION OF EVIDENCE
Herring
  contends the trial court erred in denying his motion to suppress evidence
  seized by police during the searches of his home and automobile.Â  We disagree.Â Â  
a. Initial
  Search
Herring
  contends the initial peek by police into his garage (when his black Â SUV was
  seen), was an illegal search, which thereby led to the issuance of a search warrant.Â 
  Accordingly, Herring asserts the subsequent search of his home was the
  impermissible fruit of the illegal garage search, and that police otherwise had
  no basis upon which to search the residence.Â  Herring also contends the
  subsequent SLED search of his home was illegal inasmuch as it a) resulted from
  the two prior illegal searches, and b) the SLED warrant was invalid as it was
  not issued in compliance with S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-13-140.Â  For numerous
  reasons, we find the evidence seized by police was properly admitted.Â  Â Â 
Regarding
  the initial search, Herring contends that when police crossed the curtilage of
  his yard and peered into his garage windows, it constituted an illegal search.Â 
  The trial court agreed with Herring and held Officer Linfertâ€™s peek into Herringâ€™s garage violated Herringâ€™s
  expectation of privacy. Â However, the
  trial court found that since no evidence was seized as a result of that search,
  there was nothing to suppress; it therefore went on to address the validity of
  the other searches, which it found permissible.Â  
Initially, as
  discussed below, we disagree with the trial courtâ€™s conclusion that Officer Linfertâ€™s initial peek into the garage window constituted an illegal search.Â  Regardless,
  however, we find the peek into the window did not lead to discovery of any further
  evidence, such that it was not â€œfruit of the poisonous treeâ€ and therefore did
  not taint the subsequent searches.Â  
As
  noted previously, prior to going to Herringâ€™s residence, police responded to a
  shooting at Chastityâ€™s nightclub at which the manager of the club was shot and
  killed.Â  While at Chastityâ€™s, police were given a description of Herringâ€™s
  black SUV, as well as the corresponding South Carolina license plate number
  which was written down by witnesses.Â  Police watched the video which showed the
  suspect as he entered and departed from the nightclub, and police were given a
  color photograph of the suspect from the video.Â  
Police obtained Herringâ€™s identifying information from the license
  tag number.Â  When they went to the registered address for the vehicle, a
  business office, there was no black SUV in the parking lot.Â  Officer Linfert
  checked the Department of Motor Vehicle website for other addresses listed for
  Herring, which revealed his home address.Â  Based upon this information, police
  went to the address at approximately 2:00 a.m.Â  Officer, seeing a light on in
  the garage, peeked in the garage window to see if the suspect was there.Â 
  Although the suspect was not there, Linfert saw the black SUV, and recognized it
  as the suspectâ€™s vehicle.Â  Police knocked on the door and rang the doorbell
  several times; receiving no answer, they returned to the police station and
  obtained a search warrant for the home.Â  
Private residences are places in which an individual normally
  expects privacy free of governmental intrusion not authorized by a warrant, and
  that expectation is one society recognizes as justifiable.Â  Accordingly, searches
  and seizures inside a home without a warrant are presumptively unreasonable
  absent exigent circumstances.Â  United States v. Karo, 468 U.S. 705 (1984).Â  The Fourth Amendment extends that same protection to outbuildings in the
  curtilage of the home.Â  United States v. Dunn, 480 U.S. 294 (1987); Rogers v. Pendleton, 249 F.3d 279, 287 (4th Cir.2001).[4] Â 
However, because the ultimate touchstone of the Fourth Amendment
  is â€œreasonableness,â€ the warrant requirement is subject to certain exceptions. Katz
    v. United States, 389 U.S. 347, 357 (1967).Â  The United States Supreme
  Court has recognized that one exigency obviating the requirement for a warrant
  is the need to protect or preserve life or avoid serious injury.Â  Brigham City, Utah v. Stuart, 547 U.S. 398 (2006).Â  An action is
  â€œreasonableâ€ under the Fourth Amendment, regardless of the individual officerâ€™s
  state of mind, â€œas long as the circumstances, viewed objectively, justify [the]
  action.â€ Â Scott v. United States, 436 U.S. 128, 138 (1978).Â  A fairly
  perceived need to act on the spot may justify entry and search under the
  exigent circumstances exception to the warrant requirement.Â  Schmerber v. California, 384 U.S. 757, 770-771 (1966).Â  The likelihood a suspect will imminently
  flee is also an exigency warranting such an intrusion.Â  Johnson v. United States, 333 U.S. 10, 15 (1948).Â  Protecting the safety of police officers has also been
  held an exigent circumstance.Â  Chimel v. California, 395 U.S. 752 (1969).Â  A warrantless search is justified under the exigent circumstances
  doctrine to prevent a suspect from fleeing or where there is a risk of danger
  to police or others inside or outside a dwelling. Â Minnesota v. Olson,
  495 U.S. 91, 100 (1990). Â In such circumstances, a protective sweep of the
  premises may be permitted. See Maryland v. Buie, 494 U.S. 325, 337 (1990); cf. State v. Abdullah, 357 S.C. 344, 592 S.E.2d 344
  (Ct. App. 2004).
Under the circumstances presented, we find the exigencies of the
  situation justified Officer Linfertâ€™s look into Herringâ€™s garage at 2:00 a.m.Â 
  It is undisputed that police had knowledge of Herringâ€™s identity, his
  residence, the make and model of his vehicle, and his license tag number.Â 
  Officer Linfert testified that upon arriving at the home, he saw a light on in
  the garage and therefore looked through the window to see if the suspect was
  inside.Â  Police officers were looking for a suspected murderer whom they knew
  was likely to be armed with a deadly weapon.Â  
We find it was objectively reasonable for Officer Linfert to take
  precautions to protect his own safety, and the safety of the officers around
  him, by looking into the garage to see if the suspect was there.Â  When nobody
  was in the garage, police followed proper procedure by knocking on the door and
  ringing the doorbell.Â Â  Receiving no answer, they stationed men at the house
  and went to obtain a warrant.Â  Given the exigent circumstances then and there
  presenting, we find Officer Linfertâ€™s minimal intrusion was objectively reasonable
  and did not constitute a Fourth Amendment violation.Â  Cf. Chimel v. California.Â  
Moreover, Officer Linfertâ€™s peek into the garage yielded no
  evidence against Herring.Â  Police already had knowledge of the make, model and
  license plate number of the vehicle the suspect drove; they knew the automobile
  was registered to Herring, and they knew his residential address was 406 Alexander Circle.Â  Officer Linfertâ€™s observation of the vehicle in the garage yielded no
  evidence which further inculpated Herring.Â Â  We find the trial court erred in
  holding this initial â€œsearchâ€ violated Herringâ€™s Fourth Amendment rights; the de
    minimis intrusion to secure the officersâ€™ safety did not necessitate
  suppression.

b. Search of residence
Herring next asserts the subsequently issued warrant was defective
  such that the search conducted by the Richland County Sheriffâ€™s Department
  (RCSD) was illegal.Â  He contends the affidavit supporting the warrant failed to
  connect his residence to the crime at Chastityâ€™s; he also contends the
  information in the affidavit was false because the officer who prepared the
  affidavit did not actually appear before the magistrate but, instead, sent
  another officer.Â  We find the warrant was supported by probable cause and was properly
  issued.
The affidavit states that deputies responded to Chastityâ€™s to find
  the Victim, John Johnson, who had been shot in the head and who subsequently died
  upon arrival at the hospital.Â  Witnesses at Chastityâ€™s described the suspect,
  the clothing he was wearing, the car he was driving as a black Toyota
  Forerunner, and gave the license tag number of SC 1891.Â  Department of Motor
  Vehicle records indicated the car was registered to Dewain Herring, of 1361
  Landmark Drive, which was a closed business.Â  A search of Richland County records provided an additional address for Herring at 460 Alexander Circle.Â  Based upon
  this information, the affidavit lists the property sought as â€œfirearms,
  ammunition, burgundy sweater, white turtleneck shirt, khaki pants, eyeglasses,
  black 1996 Toyota Forerunner, SC/EU1891, and any and all other evidence
  associated to a shooting incident.â€Â  
A
  search warrant may issue only upon a finding of probable cause. State v.
    Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 625 S.E.2d 216 (2006), cert. denied 129 S.Ct.
  733 (2008).Â  The duty of the reviewing court is to ensure the issuing
  magistrate had a substantial basis upon which to conclude that probable cause
  existed.Â  Id.; State v. Adams, 291 S.C. 132, 352 S.E.2d 483
  (1987).Â  A â€œtotality-of-the-circumstancesâ€ test is utilized in probable cause
  determinations:

	The task of the issuing magistrate is simply to make a practical,
  common-sense decision whether, given all the circumstances set forth in the
  affidavit before him, including the â€œveracityâ€ and â€œbasis of knowledgeâ€ of
  persons supplying hearsay information, there is a fair probability that
  contraband or evidence of a crime will be found in a particular place.

Illinois v. Gates, 462 U.S. 213, 238 (1983).Â  
We find
  the affidavit sufficient to establish probable cause for police to look for
  Herring, a murder weapon, and the Toyota Forerunner at his known residence.Â Â  
Herring
  asserts the RCSD warrant was defective because, notwithstanding the affidavit
  contained the name of Officer Linfert at the top, it was actually Officer Davis
  who appeared before the Magistrate.Â  However, Officer Linfert clarified that
  the reason his name was listed is that Officer Davis did not have a search
  warrant form on his computer, and the form was typed by Linfert on his computer
  and his name was automatically inserted at the top; Linfert simply forgot to
  change the name to Davis.Â  Officer Davis personally appeared before the
  magistrate and swore to the information; he was familiar with the information
  and background of the case, having been to Chastityâ€™s and having interviewed
  the witnesses.Â  We find the fact that Linfertâ€™s name was at the top of the
  affidavit did not vitiate the validity of the warrant.Â  State v. Shupper,
  263 S.C. 53, 207 S.E.2d 799 (1974) (typographical error did not affect validity
  of search warrant).Â  Accordingly, we find the evidence seized during the RCSDâ€™s
  search of the residence was properly admitted by the trial court.
c. SLED Search
Finally,
  Herring challenges the search performed by SLED.Â  He contends the SLED warrant,
  which was obtained by facsimile, was invalid; he also asserts the methodology
  employed, which was authorized by an order of the Chief Justice,[5] violates the search warrant statute, S.C.
  Code Ann Â§ 17-13-140.Â Â  We find the trial court properly upheld SLEDâ€™s search
  of the residence.Â Â Â  Â  Â 
SLED was called in to investigate after the sheriffâ€™s deputies wounded
  Herring during their attempt to arrest him at the home.Â  SLED obtained a
  warrant utilizing the telephone procedure set forth in the Chief Justiceâ€™s
  order of July 2001.Â  Agent Lawrence testified that he had prepared the search
  warrant, and faxed it to Magistrate McDuffie, who was in bond court.Â  The
  Magistrate swore him over the phone.Â  Although SLED was not directly
  investigating the murder, they were investigating the shooting by police
  officers, and were looking for firearms, cartridges, blood, projectiles, blood,
  and any evidence relating to a shooting incident at that address.Â  As a result
  of the search, they found the khaki pants, white turtle neck, burgundy sweater
  Herring was wearing at the time of the shooting, and two weapons, a Smith and
  Wesson .357 revolver and a Ruger .357 pistol.Â  The Ruger was in the bedroom closet
  under some clothes.Â  

	S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 17-13-140 states, in pertinent part:
	A warrant issued hereunder shall be issued only upon affidavit sworn
  to before the magistrate, municipal judicial officer, or judge of a court
  of record establishing the grounds for the warrant. If the magistrate,
  municipal judge, or other judicial officer abovementioned is satisfied that the
  grounds for the application exist or that there is probable cause to believe
  that they exist, he shall issue a warrant identifying the property and naming
  or describing the person or place to be searched. 

(Emphasis
  supplied).Â  Herring asserts the statute requires the affiant appear before the
  magistrate in person.Â  We disagree.Â  Â Â 
Contrary
  to Herringâ€™s contention, the language does not state an affidavit must be sworn
  in person.Â Â  It only requires the affidavit be sworn.Â  Officer Lawrence, who
  prepared the affidavit, was sworn over the telephone by the Magistrate.Â  We
  find this complies with the literal terms of the statute such that there was no
  defect in the warrant.Â  Cf. Gay v. Ariail, 381 S.C. 341, 673
  S.E.2d 418 (2009) (literal terms of statute prevail); Collins v. Doe,
  352 S.C. 462, 574 S.E.2d 739 (2002) (where terms of a statute are clear, there
  is no room for construction).Â  
Herring
  cites State v. McKnight, 291 S.C. 110, 352 S.E.2d 471 (1987) as
  supporting his contention that issuance of a warrant via facsimile was
  invalid.Â  In McKnight, police officers appeared before a magistrate to
  obtain a warrant, but did not complete an affidavit in support thereof.Â 
  Notwithstanding the officers were sworn and gave oral testimony to the
  magistrate, we held a â€œsearch warrant affidavit which itself is insufficient to
  establish probable cause may be supplemented before the magistrate by sworn
  oral testimony. . . . However, sworn oral testimony, standing alone, does not
  satisfy the statute.â€ 291 S.C. at 113, 352 S.e.2d at 473 (internal citations
  omitted).Â  In McKnight, we found the mandatory requirement of an
  affidavit lacking, thereby requiring suppression.Â Â  The Court noted Â§ 17-13-140
  imposes stricter requirements than does the Fourth Amendment, and that â€œ[a]
  search warrant that would survive constitutional scrutiny may still be
  defective under the statute.â€Â  Id.Â  
Recently,
  however, we recognized that there is a â€œâ€˜good faithâ€™ exception to the statuteâ€™s
  [S.C. Code Ann. 17-13-140] requirements where the officers make a good faith
  attempt to comply with the statuteâ€™s affidavit procedures.â€Â  State v. Covert,
  382 S.C. 205, 675 S.E.2d 740 (2009), citing McKnight.[6] 
We find
  the present circumstances give rise to such a good faith exception.Â  It was
  4:00 in the morning, and SLED agents were attempting to obtain a warrant to
  investigate a shooting by Richland County Sheriffâ€™s deputies of a prominent
  Columbia attorney.Â  We hold the officers made a good faith attempt to comply
  with the affidavit procedures, and accordingly, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s
  ruling.Â  Â 
Moreover,
  even if we were to hold the SLED search illegal, we would hold any error was
  harmless.Â  A videotape from Chastityâ€™s shows Herring entering and leaving the
  club.Â  Several witnesses identified Herring from the videotape, and his vehicle
  and license tag number were identified.Â  Two witnesses saw him drive away from
  the club, and then testified they saw his vehicle returning down River Drive.Â 
  Donald Hawkins saw Herringâ€™s car come back into the parking lot, saw a flash
  come from the side of the vehicle, heard John John say â€œoh shit,â€ and then saw
  that John John had been hit by a bullet.Â  Further, although Herring denied
  intentionally shooting anyone, he admitted he owns several guns, including a
  .357 Ruger, which he usually carries with him in his Toyota Forerunner, and he admitted
  he had some memory of a gun going off.Â  Finally, gunshot residue was found on
  the passenger side of the vehicle, which was ultimately connected to Herringâ€™s
  Ruger.Â  Accordingly, admission of the evidence seized in the SLED search, even
  if erroneous, was harmless.Â  State v. Gillian, 373 S.C. 601, 646 S.E.2d
  872 (2007); State v. Garner, 304 S.C. 220, 222, 403 S.E.2d 631, 632 (1991)
  (holding improperly admitted evidence harmless error given overwhelming
  evidence of guilt). Â We affirm the trial courtâ€™s ruling concerning the SLED
  search.Â  
2.Â  LAY
  OPINIONS REGARDING VIDEOTAPE
Herring
  next contends the trial court should not have allowed lay witnesses to testify
  as to what they could see on the videotape of Herring exiting Chastityâ€™s, because
  they did not personally observe the events in question but only viewed them on
  a tape; he also asserts reversible error in the denial of his motion for a
  mistrial.Â  
The
  admission or exclusion of testimonial evidence falls within the sound
  discretion of the trial court, whose decision will not be disturbed on appeal
  absent abuse resulting in prejudice.Â  State v. Holder, 382 S.C. 278, 676
  S.E.2d 690 (2009).Â  Similarly, whether to grant or deny a mistrial is within
  the discretion of the trial court and will not be reversed on appeal absent an
  abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Sweet, 374 S.C. 1, 647 S.E.2d 202
  (2007).Â  The grant of a motion for a mistrial is an extreme measure which
  should be taken only where an incident is so grievous that the prejudicial
  effect can be removed in no other way. Â State v. Beckham, 334 S.C. 302,
  513 S.E.2d 606 (1999).Â  Generally, a curative instruction to disregard the
  testimony is deemed to have cured any alleged error.Â  State v. Edwards,
  373 S.C. 230, 236, 644 S.E.2d 66, 69 (Ct.App.2007), affâ€™d as modified 2009 WL 1518780 (June 1, 2009); State v. Dawkins, 297 S.C. 386, 394, 377
  S.E.2d 298, 302 (1989) curative instructions usually cure any prejudice caused
  by the admission of incompetent evidence).
Three
  witnesses testified as to their interpretations of a video, depicting the
  outside of Chastityâ€™s at 12:05:05-12:05:06 a.m. on the night in question (which
  is the precise time when John John was shot).Â  Two witnesses, Donald Hawkins (a
  bouncer), and an Officer Gwyn, testified they saw a flash of light coming from
  the vehicle.Â  The third witness, Officer Linfert testified he saw a shot fired
  from the vehicle, later clarifying that â€œobviously we saw the video where the
  shot was fired from inside the vehicle.â€Â  
In
  response to Herringâ€™s objections to this testimony, the trial judge issued a
  curative instruction to the jury in each instance, to the effect that the
  witness could not give an opinion as to whether or not the flash was a gunshot,
  and that the jury should strike any such inference from its memory.Â  The trial
  court instructed the jury that â€œyou are the only ones who can draw from
  conclusions from what you saw on the tape and his testimony in this regard.â€ Â He
  stated, further:

	Itâ€™s the same instruction I gave you with regard to another
  witness that looked at the same video and saw what he thought was- one said a
  light, one said a shot.Â  Thatâ€™s an opinion.Â  Just take it at that.Â  Nobody saw
  the shot fired based on the testimony weâ€™ve heard so far.Â  Itâ€™s all from the
  video.Â Â  You are going to have the video.Â  You can look at it.Â  You can
  determine whatever you choose to determine from it.

As to Gwynâ€™s
  testimony, the trial court re-instructed, â€œthis witness has repeated something
  that another witness said regarding a light or a flash.Â  You are not to
  interpret that as any evidence of a gunshot wound again or a gunshot.Â Â  It is
  your responsibility to see what you see on the video, if you see anything.Â 
  This witness has merely told you what he thinks he saw.â€Â Â  
We find
  the trial courtâ€™s curative instructions sufficient to cure any prejudice, such
  that there was no error in denying Herringâ€™s motions for a mistrial.Â  State
    v. Kelsey, 331 S.C. 50, 502 S.E.2d 63 (1998) (grant of a mistrial is an
  extreme measure which should be taken only where an incident is so grievous
  that prejudicial effect can be removed in no other way); Dawkins, supra.
  Â Â 
Herringâ€™s convictions and sentences are affirmed.[7]
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J. and BEATTY, J., concur. KITTREDGE, J., concurring in a separate opinion in
  which PLEICONES, J., concurs.

JUSTICE
  KITTREDGE:Â  I concur in affirming the
  convictions and sentence of H. Dewain Herring.Â  I join the majority in all
  respects save its determination concerning the initial search.Â  I disagree that,
  from an objective standard, exigent circumstances existed upon the arrival of
  law enforcement at Herringâ€™s residence two hours after the shooting of John Johnson
  at Chastityâ€™s strip club.
What
  the majority characterizes as a â€œpeek by police into [Herringâ€™s] garageâ€ was,
  in my judgment, an unwarranted trespass and warrantless search.Â  Upon the
  arrival of the police at Herringâ€™s residence approximately two hours after the
  crime, exigent circumstances for Fourth Amendment purposes did not exist.Â  More
  to the point, nothing occurred at the residence to create an exigency to
  justify a warrantless search.Â  There was neither hot pursuit, nor an imminent
  threat of danger to police or others, nor other conditions that reasonably fit
  exigent circumstances jurisprudence. Â See State v. Abdullah, 357 S.C.
  344, 351, 592 S.E.2d 344, 348 (Ct. App. 2004) (discussing
  law of exigent circumstances).Â  
The
  majority acknowledges that at the time of â€œOfficer Linfertâ€™s peek into the
  garage â€¦[,] [i]t is undisputed that police had knowledge of Herringâ€™s identity,
  his residence, the make and model of his vehicle, and his license tag number.â€Â 
  The police responded to this purported exigent circumstance by ringing the
  doorbell.Â  When no one answered the doorbell, police â€œstationed men at the
  house and went to obtain a warrant.â€Â  Even from a subjective point, it is clear
  that law enforcement did not harbor the view that exigent circumstances
  justified a warrantless search.Â  
Although
  I believe the peek into the garage constituted an illegal search, I agree with
  the majority that the search yielded no evidence.Â  The evidence at the
  residence linking Herring to the shooting was seized as a result of the
  subsequent valid SLED search warrant.Â  
PLEICONES, J.,
  concurs.


[1] The appeal was certified to this Court from the Court of Appeals on motion of
  counsel for Herring.Â  
[2]Â  Several officers remained outside the premises
  while the warrant was obtained.
[3] Â SLED searched the residence relative to the shooting which
  occurred between police and Herring at the time of Herringâ€™s arrest.Â  
[4]Â  It is equally well settled that searches and
  seizures of property in plain view are presumptively reasonable.Â  What a person
  knowingly exposes to the public, even in his own home or office, is not a
  subject of Fourth Amendment protection.Â  California v. Ciraolo, 476 U.S. 207, 213 (1986) (quoting Katz v. United States, 389 U.S. 347, 351 (1967).
[5] Â See http://www.sccourts.org/courtOrders/displayOrder.cfm?orderNo=2001-07-26-01.Â 
  The order was issued pursuant to Art. V, Â§ 4 of the SC CONST (Chief Justice of
  the Supreme Court shall be the administrative head of the unified judicial
  system).Â  The order allows for issuance of search warrants by facsimile under
  controlled conditions, and sets forth the requirements therefore.Â  
[6]Â  In Covert, we left open the question of
  whether a good faith exception applies when â€œthe officers reasonably believe
  the warrant is valid when the search is made, but is subsequently determined to
  be invalid.â€Â  Id. at ___, 675 S.E.2d at 742-743.Â  Given our recognition of an exception for officersâ€™
  good faith attempt to comply with the affidavit requirement, we find no reason
  not to extend such a good faith exception to a warrant reasonably believed to
  be valid, but later determined invalid.Â  Accordingly, even if we were to
  determine the affidavit was improper, we would find the SLED agents acted in
  good faith and reasonably believed the warrant valid, such that the search
  should be upheld.
[7]Â  The remaining issues are affirmed pursuant to
  SCACR Rule 220(B)(1) and the following authorities:Â  Issue 4 (failure to charge
  the law of accident)- State v. Burriss, 334 S.C. 256, 259, 513 S.E.2d
  104, 106 (1999) (for homicide to be excusable on the ground of accident, it
  must be shown that the killing was unintentional, the defendant was acting
  lawfully, and due care was exercised in the handling of the weapon); State
    v. Burkhart, 350 S.C. 252, 565 S.E.2d 298 (2002) (to warrant reversal,
  trial court's refusal to give requested charge must be both erroneous and
  prejudicial to defendant): Issue 5 (involuntary manslaughter instruction)- State
    v. McKnight, 378 S.C. 33, 661 S.E.2d 354 (2008) (failure to give requested
  jury instructions is not prejudicial error where instructions given adequately
  cover the law): Issue 6 (State v. Mouzon instruction) - State v.
    Reese, 370 S.C.31, 633 S.E.2d 898 (2006) (upholding Mouzon instruction); Battle v. State, 382 S.C. 197, 675 S.E.2d 736 (2009) (in
  determining prejudiced from jury instructions, court must find that, viewing
  the charge in its entirety and not in isolation, there is a reasonable likelihood
  that the jury applied the instruction in a way that violates the Constitution):
  Issue 7 (directed verdict) - State v. Pittman, 373 S.C. 527, 647 S.E.2d
  144 (2007) (if State presents any evidence from which the defendantâ€™s guilt can
  be fairly and logically deduced, case must go to the jury): Issue 8 (cumulative
  error) - State v. Gaines, 380 S.C. 23, 667 S.E.2d 728 (2008) (to qualify
  for reversal on ground of cumulative effect of trial errors, defendant must
  demonstrate errors adversely affected right to fair trial).Â  Â
